data.text: INDEX
Appendix A – Routine maternal observations for women in labour with fever, suspected
sepsis or sepsis
Appendix B – PROMPT Risk Assessment and Action for Suspected Maternal Sepsis
Appendix C – Management of Pyrexia in Labour
Appendix D - Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose
The purpose of this guideline is to provide guidance on the management of antenatal, intrapartum and postnatal sepsis, and the management of pyrexia in labour
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix D)
Background and Introduction

Sepsis is one of the leading causes of direct maternal death in the UK; maternal mortality from sepsis is 8 per 100,000 live births. This is partly because the immunological changes naturally occurring during pregnancy together with increased exposure to healthcare, and additional risks such as with premature rupture of membranes or gestational diabetes, mean a pregnant woman is more susceptible to infection than her non-pregnant counterpart.

Sepsis is defined as life-threatening organ dysfunction caused by a dysregulated host response to infection. This emphasizes the primacy of the nonhomeostatic host response to infection, the potential lethality that is considerably in excess of a straightforward infection, and the need for urgent recognition. Even a modest degree of organ dysfunction when infection is first suspected is associated with in-hospital mortality in excess of 10%. Therefore, recognition of this condition merits a prompt and appropriate response.
Septic shock is as above + refractory hypotension AND persistently raised lactate (>2mmol/l) despite 30 mls/kg volume resuscitation with Hartmann's Solution or Normal Saline.
Etiology
The most common pathogens are:

Group A Beta-Haemolytic Streptococcus which causes puerperal sepsis by endometritis and is a common cause of wound infections, cellulitis and necrotising fasciitis. Group A streptococcus can rapidly progress to septic shock;
Group B Beta-Haemolytic Streptococcus which is strongly associated with neonatal sepsis and endocarditis;
E-coli is a common cause of gram negative sepsis usually secondary to urinary tract infection or abdominal sepsis, it accounts for one third of episodes of sepsis;
Staphylococcus aureus is a common pathogen in mastitis and surgical wound infections;
Streptococcus pneumoniae;
MRSA, Clostridium septicum and Morganella morganii.
Primary sources of infection

table_items.text: Headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, non-blanching rash
Cough, sputum, dyspnoea, pleuritic chest pain, sore throat
Send sputum sample for culture. Send throat swab for culture. Need input from respiratory physician + medical microbiologist
Mastalgia, redness, lumpy engorged breast, fever, rigors
May lead to breast abscesses, necrotising fasciitis and TSS. Persistent spiking temperature suggests abscess
Abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, bowel disturbances, diarrhoea
Pelvic collection, cholecystitis, pancreatitis, appendicitis, peritonitis
Offensive smelling lochia/liquor, constant severe abdominal pain and tenderness, uterine tenderness, delay in uterine involution, heavy and or/persistent bleeding
Common source of sepsis in pregnant and postpartum women, and is a leading cause of maternal mortality *account for a history of prolonged rupture of membranes
Dysuria, frequency of micturition, loin tenderness

E.coli common cause. Send MSU for culture if leucocytes, protein & blood present. If IDC suspected as source, remove or change as soon as practicable. Repeat MSU post- positive culture and treatment to confirm clearance
Wound erythema, discharge, tenderness, constant severe abdominal pain, black
Swab any discharge for culture. Persistent spiking temperature suggests abscess. Refer for surgical
Erythema or pus at line site +/- tracking cellulitis
Swab any discharge for culture. Intravenous cannula sites should be recorded & inspected twice daily

data.text: *skin and soft-tissue infections are particularly associated with toxic shock syndromes (TSS). Any widespread rash could suggest early TSS, especially if redness in the scelera is present
Risk Factors
Women who are pregnant, have given birth or had a termination of pregnancy or miscarriage in the past 6 weeks are in a high risk group for sepsis.
Risk factors for obstetric sepsis:
Obesity;
Gestational diabetes, diabetes or other comorbidities;
Impaired immune systems because of illness or drugs (e.g. HIV, previous chemotherapy) / immunosuppressant medication(e.g. steroid treatment, transplant patients);
Anaemia;
Continued vaginal bleeding or an offensive vaginal discharge;
History of pelvic infection;
Amniocentesis and other invasive procedures;
Cervical cerclage;
Prolonged rupture of membranes;
Invasive procedures such as caesarean section, instrumental deliveries, manual removal of placenta or removal of retained products of conception
Vaginal trauma (perineal repair)
wound haematoma;
Retained products of conception post miscarriage or post-delivery;
Close contact with someone with group A streptococcal infection;
Black or minority ethnic group origin

Causes and risk factors unrelated to pregnancy should also be considered; many infections are acquired in the community without there being one single event obvious in the history to suggest infection.
Assessment
Think ‘could this be sepsis?' at an early stage when presented with an unwell, pregnant or recently pregnant woman.

Thenatural adaptations to the body with pregnancy may mask the signs and symptoms of infection or an acute abdomen until the woman deteriorates. Symptoms may be less distinctive, for example feeling very unwell; therefore a high index of suspicion is necessary.
Clinical signs suggestive of sepsis include one or more of the following:
Pyrexia ≥ 38c or 37.5-37.9c on two consecutive occasions (1 hour apart);
Hypothermia < 36c;
Tachycardia >90bpm or ≥100bpm in pregnant women;
Tachypnoea ≥20bpm;
Hypoxia SpO2 <92% without O2;
Hypotension systolic BP ≤100
Oliguria - no urine output for 12-18hours (<0.5ml/kg/hour)
Impaired consciousness;
Failure to respond to treatment.

Vital signs should be recorded on the modified early obstetric warning system (MEOWS) found in the antenatal/labour/postnatal care records. These should include: respiratory rate, pulse, blood pressure, temperature, oxygen saturations, urine output and AVPU for all assessments and monitor the score (the shift co-ordinator must be informed of any patients with a MEOWS score of 3 or more, using the MEOWS trigger process).

It is the response to an abnormal score that will have an impact on the outcome, not simply its documentation; escalate for senior obstetric review where there are concerns and always consider the woman's clinical condition alongside the MEOWS score.

Use the PROMPT Risk Assessment and Action for Suspected Maternal Sepsis tool (Appendix B) when assessing these women to stratify their risk (low, moderate and high) and keep it in the medical records (extra care is needed if a person cannot give a good history, for example people with English as a second language or people with communication problems).
Escalate for obstetric review (ST3 or higher) for sepsis assessment within one hour where there is a suspicion of infection/MEOWS has triggered and 1+ ‘moderate risk' criteria are present.
Moderate risk criteria:
Respiratory rate 21-24rpm;
Heart rate 100-130bpm;
Systolic BP 91-100mmgh;
Temperature <36˚c;
No urine output 12-18 hours;
Fetal heart > 160bpm/pathological CTG;
Prolonged spontaneous rupture of membranes (SROM);
Recent invasive procedure;
Bleeding/wound infection/vaginal discharge/abdominal pain;
Close contact with Group A Strepococcus;
Relatives concerned about mental/functional status
Diabetes/gestational diabetes/immunosuppressed.
Escalate for immediate obstetric review (ST3 or higher) where one or more ‘high risk' criteria are present. Transfer to the obstetric-led unit if in the community.
High Risk criteria:
Respiratory rate ≥25rpm;
Sp02;
Heart rate >130bpm;
Systolic BP ≤90mmgh;
Altered mental status /responds only to voice, pain or unresponsive;
Blood lactate ≥2.0*;
Non-blanching rash/mottled/cyanotic;
Urine <0.5ml/kg/hour;
No urine for 18 hours;
*lactate measurement may be transiently elevated during and immediately after normal labour and birth. If unsure repeat sample.
Investigations
Blood cultures are important and should be obtained by a trained practitioner prior to antibiotic administration.
A venous blood gas including serum lactate and glucose should be measured promptly, and within one hour where high risk criteria is identified.
Blood tests should include:
Full blood count (FBC);
Urea and electrolytes (U+E;)
C-reactive protein (CRP);
Liver function test (LFT);
Creatinine;
Clotting.
Any relevant imaging studies should be performed promptly in an attempt to confirm the source of infection; this could include a chest X-ray, CT, pelvic and abdominal ultrasound scan.
If the MRSA status of the woman is unknown, a pre-moistened nose swab may be sent for rapid MRSA screening.

Samples taken and sent for culture should be guided by clinical suspicion of focus of infection; throat swab, mid-stream urine, high vaginal swab, placental swabs, sputum, cerebrospinal fluid, epidural site swab, caesarean section or episiotomy wound swabs and expressed breast milk should ideally be obtained prior to starting antibiotic therapy as the results may become un-informative within a few hours of commencing antibiotics (repeat MSU post-positive culture and treatment to confirm clearance).

If infection suspected during labour or birth (offensive liquor, baby in poor condition) swabs should be taken from vagina, placenta, and baby (ear and umbilicus) and the neonatal team, should be informed. Ask the neonatal team if swabs from the baby have grown any organisms.

If diarrhoea is particularly offensive, a stool sample should be submitted for clostridium difficile toxin testing. A history of diarrhoea warrants routine culture (Refer to Clostridium Difficile; register number 06024).

Results of lab tests should be checked and recorded regularly. The medical microbiologist should be consulted to ensure specimens are processed appropriately and results communicated directly to the clinician at the earliest opportunity.
Management of Sepsis
Where high risk criteria are identified/ organ dysfunctions are present commence the ‘sepsis six' pathway immediately (within the first hour). (Refer to Appendix B)
Intravenous antibiotics – refer to the Trust Microguide for current guidance on antimicrobial prescribing.
Monitor using MEOWS and record observations every  minutes if the patient triggers 3 or more (as per the MEOWS trigger process).
Declare ‘sepsis', similar to activation of the major obstetric haemorrhage protocol, to ensure the relevant members of the multidisciplinary team are informed, aware and act.
Team to include, with preferably one named obstetric lead:
Midwife coordinator;
Senior/consultant obstetrician;
Senior obstetric anaesthetist;
Microbiologist;
Intensive/critical care team.
A clear plan should be made in conjunction with the woman/family members and the plan should be reviewed regularly, taking account of the whole clinical picture, including response to treatment.
Remember care bundles for critical illness:
Blood glucose control: aim for blood glucose 6-10mmol/L;
Thromboprophylaxis: compression stockings, intermittent pneumatic compression devices, low molecular weight heparin;
Stress ulcer prophylaxis: regular PPI (e.g. omeprazole) or H2-receptor antagonist (e.g. ranitidine);
IV paracetamol for persistent pyrexia.
There should be a low threshold for women with sepsis or septic shock to be nursed in a high dependency or intensive care setting.
Indications for admission of the woman to ICU:
Cardiovascular – hypotension ( SBP < 90mmHg) and/or raised serum lactate persisting despite fluid resuscitation (lactate >4mmol/L), severe acidaemia pH <7.20;
Respiratory – respiratory distress despite oxygen administration, respiratory rate >25, low saturations ± Pa02 on arterial blood gas whilst on high flow oxygen, pulmonary oedema, airway protection;
Renal – low or no urine output, raising urea and creatinine, may need temporary renal replacement therapy;
Neurological – consciousness level does not return to normal or uncontrolled agitation;
Miscellaneous - multiorgan failure, uncorrected acidosis, hypothermia.
(Refer to guideline 04232 Assist Medical and Midwifery Staff in the Provision of High Dependency Care and Arrangements for Safe and Timely Transfer to ITU)
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) should be avoided for pain relief in cases of sepsis as they impede the ability of polymorphs to fight GAS infection.
For fluid balance monitoring – if the patient can self-void and is fully mobile, measure urine output. Otherwise consider the use of a Foley's catheter where this is not practicable.

Extreme caution should be exercised in women with pre-eclampsia and fluid therapy/intravenous fluid resuscitation; they require specialist care. Seek advice and continued support from an obstetric anaesthetist before giving fluid boluses.
Antibiotic Treatment
Administration of IV antibiotics within one hour of recognition of sepsis.
Refer to the Trust Microguide for up-to-date guidance on antibiotic prescribing.
An obstetrician should review the results of any investigations requested at the earliest opportunity.

If there is no response to treatment within 24-48 hours or the condition is deteriorating at any point, the patient should be promptly reviewed by the on-call consultant obstetrician, and a consultant microbiologist involved for antibiotic guidance.
For microbiology advice contact a consultant microbiologist on extension 5019. For out of hours, go via switchboard.
Considerations in the Antenatal Period

Sepsis that occurs during pregnancy is termed ‘maternal sepsis'; it can be as a direct result of the pregnancy or an indirect cause unrelated to the pregnancy. The commonest sources are urinary tract and chorioamnionitis.

Use PROMPTs Risk Assessment and Action for suspected sepsis tool (Appendix B) when assessing any woman where there is a suspicion of sepsis, i.e. feeling unwell, triggering MEOWS, and/or presenting with any signs/symptoms of sepsis.
The fetal heart should be monitored and a CTG commenced if appropriate.

In a critically ill pregnant woman, birth of the baby may be considered if it would be beneficial to the mother or the baby or to both. A decision on the timing and mode of birth should be made by a senior obstetrician following discussion with the woman if her condition allows.
If preterm delivery is anticipated, cautious consideration should be given to the use of antenatal corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity in the woman with sepsis.
Considerations for Women in Labour
Women in labour with sepsis are at higher risk of severe illness or death.

Use PROMPTs Risk Assessment and Action for suspected sepsis tool (Appendix B) when assessing any woman where there is a suspicion of sepsis, i.e. feeling unwell, triggering MEOWS, and/or presenting with any signs/symptoms of sepsis.
See Appendix A for routine maternal observations for women in labour with fever, suspected sepsis or sepsis.
Continuous electronic fetal monitoring is recommended.
Fetal blood sample (FBS) results may be falsely reassuring; always discuss with a consultant obstetrician whether FBS is needed (refer to guideline 08014A Fetal Blood Sampling).
Regional anaesthesia should only be used with caution and advice from a consultant obstetric anaesthetist, and with a senior anaesthetist present.
Management of Pyrexia in Labour

In labour physiological changes and epidural can lead to clinical features similar to sepsis. Pyrexia, tachycardia, tachypnoea, leucocytosis can be present in the absence of sepsis. However treatment with IV antibiotics should be commenced, in order to ensure that the golden opportunity of early treatment is not missed in a small number of women who actually have sepsis in labour, which will be apparent if the features of suspected sepsis persist post delivery.
Continuous electronic fetal monitoring is recommended in the presence of maternal pyrexia.
See Appendix C for management of pyrexia in labour.
Consider (IV) paracetamol but be aware that it is not a treatment for sepsis and should not delay investigation if sepsis is suspected.
Considerations in the Postnatal Period
The commonest source is the genital tract and in particular the uterus, resulting in endometritis.

Common symptoms include fever, diarrhoea, vomiting, abdominal pain, generalised maculopapular rash (staphylococcal or streptococcal sepsis), offensive vaginal discharge and signs of infection in caesarean wounds.

Use PROMPTs Risk Assessment and Action for suspected sepsis tool (Appendix B) when assessing any woman where there is a suspicion of sepsis, i.e. feeling unwell, triggering MEOWS, and/or presenting with any signs/symptoms of sepsis. Note to exclude fetal heart/CTG criteria when assessing postnatal women.
The focus of infection should be sought and dealt with, for example uterine evacuation or drainage of a breast, wound or pelvic abscess.
Administration of IV antibiotics - see trust Microguide for up-to-date guidance on antimicrobial prescribing.
For women who had pyrexia in labour and the immediate postnatal period (within 6 hours of birth), refer to Appendix B.

Community midwives who are carrying out postnatal visits should carry a thermometer to enable them to check the temperature of women who are unwell. If sepsis is suspected in the community, urgent and early referral to hospital is indicated.
Postnatal women who attend the hospital multiple times with symptoms should have a full systematic examination to diagnose and instigate management of sepsis early.
Involvement of Other Specialties
All cases of sepsis should be discussed with a clinical microbiologist.

Women with previously documented carriage of or infection with multi-resistant organisms (e.g. ESBL producing organisms, MRSA, GAS or PVL-producing staphylococci) should prompt notification of the infection control team.
Suspicion of necrotising fasciitis should prompt involvement of intensive care physicians and referral for surgical opinion, ideally from plastic and reconstructive surgeons if available.
Where additional clinical support is required, the Trigger and Response Team (TaRT) can be contacted between 0800-2200hrs on bleep #6555 2043/2030.
Neonatal Considerations

Parenteral antibiotic treatment given to the woman for confirmed or suspected invasive bacterial infection (such as septicaemia) at any time during labour, or in the 24-hour periods before and after the birth (this does not refer to intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis) is a ‘red flag' for the baby to commence antibiotic treatment. Prompt referral to a neonatologist should be made.
The baby is especially at risk of streptococcal and staphylococcal infection during birth and during breastfeeding.

If infection is suspected during labour or birth (offensive liquor, baby born in poor condition) swabs should be taken from the vagina, placenta, and baby (ear and umbilicus) and the neonatal team informed. Ask the neonatal team if swabs from the baby have grown any organisms.
Debriefing and Discharge
All swabs, blood and culture results should be checked and acted upon where necessary prior to discharge home. The results should be communicated to the woman.
Give women who have been assessed for sepsis but have been discharged without a diagnosis of sepsis (and their family or carers, if appropriate) verbal and written information about:
What sepsis is, and why it was suspected;
What tests and investigations have been done;
Instructions about which symptoms to monitor;
When to get medical attention if their illness continues;
How to get medical attention if they need to seek help urgently;
Confirm that people understand the information they have been given, and what actions they should take to get help if they need it.

The women and their families and/or carers must be informed appropriately if they have had sepsis. Give them the opportunity to discuss their concerns. Verbal and written information should be given about:
Why they developed sepsis;
Whether they are likely to develop sepsis again;
If more investigations are necessary;
Details of any community care needed for example, related to peripherally inserted central venous catheters (PICC) lines or other intravenous catheters/perineal wounds/ LSCS wounds;
What they should expect during recovery;
Arrangements for follow-up, including specific critical care follow up if relevant;
Possible short-term and long-term problems.

Any problems noted during a woman's hospital stay should be reported directly (via discharge notification) to her community carer (GP, midwives and health visitors) when she is discharged so that appropriate follow up/visits can be arranged.

All postnatal women, especially those who are discharged early should be informed of the possible signs and symptoms of conditions, including sepsis that may threaten their lives and require them to access emergency treatment. Information on how to get prompt medical assessment, including hospital telephone numbers and emergency care should be given.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills PROMPT training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Professional Midwifery Advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices. PMA's are available from 08:00 – 16:00, 5 days a week rota via switchboard.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.

All staff should ensure that they follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention. All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using High Impact Intervention guidelines to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care.

If a group A streptococcal infection is suspected or confirmed, the woman must be placed in a side room and contact precautions should be applied for up to 48hrs following effective antibiotic therapy. The infection control team must be informed.
Healthcare workers should wear personal protective equipment including disposable gloves and aprons when in contact with the woman, equipment and their immediate surroundings.

Breaks in the skin of the woman or carer must be covered with a waterproof dressing. Fluid-repellent surgical masks with visors must be used at operative debridement /change of dressings of GAS necrotising fasciitis and for other procedures where droplet spread is possible.
Visitors should be offered suitable information and relevant personal protective equipment while the woman is isolated.

When more than one case of sepsis is diagnosed at the same time with the same micro- organism, urgent consideration should be given to the possibility of a contaminated area in the maternity unit and/or carriage of the micro-organism by staff members. In such circumstances the consultant obstetrician, matron and consultant microbiologist must meet, it may be necessary to undertake a look-back exercise to identify the source and an action plan formulated.

Mothers or neonates infected or colonised with high-risk organisms such as GAS, MRSA or PVL-producing staphylococci may generate outbreaks within the healthcare setting, especially for other babies in nursery units and staff. The infection control team should be informed of any such cases and appropriate isolation precautions followed.

Non-maternity isolations of GAS – for example, when known about before the patient is admitted, or diagnosed in a healthcare worker – should be reported to the infection control team/occupational health, as appropriate.

The Health Protection Agency has produced detailed guidelines for investigation, control and prevention of spread of GAS infection in healthcare settings in the UK. Generally, prophylaxis for GAS organisms would be administered in the event of close contact (kissing or household contacts) and for healthcare workers with exposure to respiratory secretions (e.g. suctioning).
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's newsletter that is sent via email to all staff.
References

A change to an existing policy
A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
Who benefits from this change and how?
